{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3497773,"name":"Alex","username":"aopalka","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/f9ae1b/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-01-31T13:27:16.478Z","cooked":"

I was wondering what the best way to simulate the lasercan hardware. Is there an expected process for this ? Other than setting range to known values in code. Any recommendations or best practices?

@Jaci

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2025-01-31T13:27:16.478Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":38,"reads":314,"readers_count":313,"score":257.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":484466,"topic_slug":"simulating-lasercan","display_username":"Alex","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":56954,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/simulating-lasercan/484466/1","custom_user_title":"Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3497833,"name":"Chris Gerth","username":"gerthworm","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gerthworm/{size}/268658_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-31T14:27:40.319Z","cooked":"

One thing that you know, but Jaci (and the Lasercan libraries) won’t: What is your hardware pointed at on the real robot?

I would expect any simulation solution requires code that’s only for simulation, and specific in your robot, to calculate the distance from “thing it’s pointed at” to “sensor face”.

Once you have this distance,

aopalka:

Other than setting range to known values in code.

Surely this would be the easiest way?

if (isSimulation()):
   sensorReading = simSpecificCalculation()
else:
   sensorReading = readHardware()

# do something with sensorReading
","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2025-01-31T14:27:40.319Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":304,"readers_count":303,"score":75.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":484466,"topic_slug":"simulating-lasercan","display_username":"Chris Gerth","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24617,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/simulating-lasercan/484466/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3497835,"name":"","username":"nstrike","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nstrike/{size}/167038_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-31T14:32:01.159Z","cooked":"

Probably, or you can be lazy and use the sim hw pane and modify the distance there.

I made my own sim class for LaserCAN just so i could do this that you can use. @Jaci is coming up with a better one soon too

github.com

BroncBotz3481/YAGSLTestCode2025/blob/main/src/main/java/frc/robot/subsystems/LaserCanSim.java

package frc.robot.subsystems;

import au.grapplerobotics.ConfigurationFailedException;
import au.grapplerobotics.interfaces.LaserCanInterface;
import edu.wpi.first.hal.SimBoolean;
import edu.wpi.first.hal.SimDevice;
import edu.wpi.first.hal.SimDevice.Direction;
import edu.wpi.first.hal.SimDeviceJNI;
import edu.wpi.first.hal.SimEnum;
import edu.wpi.first.hal.SimInt;

public class LaserCanSim implements LaserCanInterface
{

  private final SimDevice  simDevice;
  private final SimEnum    m_status;
  private final SimInt     m_distancemm;
  private final SimInt     m_ambient;
  private final SimBoolean m_islong;
  private final SimEnum    m_timingBudget;

For varying definitions of “easy”.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2025-01-31T14:34:51.156Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":5,"reads":237,"readers_count":236,"score":117.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":484466,"topic_slug":"simulating-lasercan","display_username":"Chris Gerth","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24617,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/simulating-lasercan/484466/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3498375,"name":"Jaci","username":"Jaci","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jaci/{size}/8002_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-31T21:51:39.507Z","cooked":"

There is currently a MockLaserCan class that exposes the same interface (LaserCanInterface) as a real LaserCan, and will let you set values using that class. I’m working on another class backed by SimDevice that can be edited in the simulation GUI, but in either case it’s a class that’s substituted from your real LaserCAN when you’re in a simulation environment. This is much closer to what’s done in industry.

You can get started now by replacing your LaserCan instance coming into your classes with LaserCanInterface (from which LaserCan derives), and using MockLaserCan in simulation - to be replaced with a new class in the next week or so that pipes to the simulation gui.

Looks pretty cool.

I’ve noticed a lot of try/catching is needed to ensure safety when creating/using the LaserCan. Any thoughts on making the failures states less damaging the a running robot?

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2025-02-04T19:24:21.190Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":185,"readers_count":184,"score":42.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":484466,"topic_slug":"simulating-lasercan","display_username":"Nicholas Armstrong","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":24335,"username":"Jaci","name":"Jaci","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jaci/{size}/8002_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":48345,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/simulating-lasercan/484466/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3502167,"name":"Jaci","username":"Jaci","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jaci/{size}/8002_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-04T20:59:38.135Z","cooked":"

Those are necessary to make sure the configuration status is known to the user. There are internal retries to make sure that those instances where an exception are thrown are in the minority, but in the case where a configuration doesn’t apply properly or the LaserCAN is missing from the bus, we’ve generally taken the design consideration that the user should decide how to handle that error.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2025-02-04T20:59:38.135Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":178,"readers_count":177,"score":40.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":484466,"topic_slug":"simulating-lasercan","display_username":"Jaci","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":48345,"username":"narmstro","name":"Nicholas Armstrong","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/n/5e9695/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24335,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Grapple | FRC 10350"},"post_url":"/t/simulating-lasercan/484466/7","custom_user_title":"Grapple | FRC 10350","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3505054,"name":"Nicholas Armstrong","username":"narmstro","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/n/5e9695/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-07T15:38:40.905Z","cooked":"

I can understand that. However the LaserCan constructor calls System.exit inside a try catch block. I don’t believe System.exit would throw an exception that I can handle at my call to the LaserCan constructor.

Nevermind. I thought that was causing the issue. It looks like if something were to go back it would happen after the try/catch.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2025-02-07T15:46:04.797Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":149,"readers_count":148,"score":34.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":484466,"topic_slug":"simulating-lasercan","display_username":"Nicholas Armstrong","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":48345,"username":"narmstro","name":"Nicholas Armstrong","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/n/5e9695/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":48345,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/simulating-lasercan/484466/9","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3505568,"name":"Jaci","username":"Jaci","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jaci/{size}/8002_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-07T23:27:02.454Z","cooked":"

Yea, for reference that System.exit() call is only if it fails to load from JNI, which means the native system library for libgrapplefrc isn’t present. That’s a fatal error since it means something in the environment is broken and needs to be remedied before the library can be used
